From amit at sdsc.edu  Wed Feb 26 18:23:13 2014
From: amit at sdsc.edu (Chourasia, Amit)
Date: Wed, 26 Feb 2014 23:23:13 +0000
Subject: [Paraview] apply texture to a slice
Message-ID: <98374461-5382-44E0-9C01-FF4D6C7890C5@sdsc.edu>

Hello,

I am trying to apply a texture to a slice, my web search and maillist search gave me old methods which are not longer applicable for 4.x release.

Here is what I am doing

1) Load a 3d unigrid scalar data as xdmf
2) apply slice filter
3) apply texture map to plane

Under "Display" the only extra thing which becomes available is texture coordinates, there is no option to load texture file.

When I follow Burlen's example here, I only see "Prevent Seam" in properties panel  
http://www.paraview.org/pipermail/paraview/2013-April/028006.html

What am I missing?
Thanks
-Amit



From amit at sdsc.edu  Wed Feb 26 18:58:36 2014
From: amit at sdsc.edu (Chourasia, Amit)
Date: Wed, 26 Feb 2014 23:58:36 +0000
Subject: [Paraview] Potential Coordinate system bug in XDMF 2D reader
In-Reply-To: <3FB3DE02-977A-4526-BCB3-A075D6C5CC47@sdsc.edu>
References: <3FB3DE02-977A-4526-BCB3-A075D6C5CC47@sdsc.edu>
Message-ID: <9F15C08D-6009-43B4-A1BC-AD35E0858745@sdsc.edu>

Found a work around for the time being.
Just load the 2D unigrid data as 3D which is one cell deep, then use slice or extract surface filter.
This way the data shows up in paraview in same coordinate system for both my grids

-A





On Feb 19, 2014, at 12:08 PM,  wrote:

> Hello,
> 
> I have a 3d and 2d unigrid data wrapped with a XDMF header, they do not show up in same coordinate space as they should in Paraview, in VisIt they show up fine. This could potentially be a bug when parsing XDMF data in Paraview, I am sharing example data at URL below, perhaps someone can take a  quick look and confirm
> http://users.sdsc.edu/~amit/forums/xdmf.zip
> 
> Cheers
> -A

On Wed, Feb 26, 2014 at 10:23 AM, Thomas, Christian
<c.thomas at imperial.ac.uk> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
>
> I have a problem with the plot-over-line filter.
>
> I'm trying to plot velocity profiles along the normals to a given body or surface. If I use the volume solution as input to plot-over-line, some sections of the velocity profiles are omitted - for whatever reason they are set to zero or NANS. However, if I use a slice filter (or a plane) of the volume as input to plot-over-line, then the velocity profiles are complete. Note that I have used the same values for point1 and point2 in plot-over-line. See the attached file that depicts an example of the velocity profiles for dashed blue the volume input and solid red the slice input. (Note that the data omissions for the volume input can appear anywhere in the profile).
>
> I have to generate many profiles (1000s) at different surface positions, so for time reasons, it would be more convenient to use only the volume input. For a slice as input I would need to form a suitable slice/plane for each surface station - it is assumed that each surface position would require a different plane.
>
> I hope the above makes sense.
>
> Is this just a random bug in Paraview or can I overcome this problem.
> Any suggestions or help are greatly appreciated.
> Thomas

Amit,

I think you're just forgetting to switch to advanced mode on the
properties panel (or search for "texture") (refer to
http://www.kitware.com/blog/home/post/491). You'll see the "Texture"
combo-box to load texture under the "Miscellaneous" group. Image
attached.

Utkarsh

clicking the "gear" button next the color editor widget that will show
up a table widget allowing you to edit the values (Image attacged).

From hongyi at renci.org  Thu Feb 27 13:35:54 2014
From: hongyi at renci.org (Hong Yi)
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 2014 18:35:54 +0000
Subject: [Paraview] undefined reference to `gzopen64' when building
 ParaView on Titan with PrgEnv-gnu/4.2.34 - SOLVED
Message-ID: <65F8B323A072504ABFC5D3D87519105150047CEF@MAIL-MBX2.ad.renci.org>

Just a quick follow-up update in case it helps the next person who run into the similar problem: I have fixed this problem by setting the option to NOT use system zlib (which does not contain gzopen64 symbol), so it can build zlib from VTK thirdparty directory which will contain gzopen64 symbol. Now ParaView built successfully in the updated software environment on Titan.

Regards,
Hong

From: ParaView [mailto:paraview-bounces at paraview.org] On Behalf Of Hong Yi
Sent: Tuesday, February 25, 2014 5:40 PM
To: paraview at paraview.org
Subject: [Paraview] undefined reference to `gzopen64' when building ParaView on Titan with PrgEnv-gnu/4.2.34

I have successfully built ParaView (version 4.0.1) for our in-situ visualization using the previous default PrgEnv-gnu environment with gcc 4.7.2 last year, and is currently trying to build it again with the updated default PrgEnv-gnu environment PrgEnv-gnu/4.2.34 with gcc 4.8.2, and run into "undefined reference to gzopen64" errors at the final linking phase. Then I discovered I am linking to /usr/lib64/libz.a which only contains gzopen (i.e., does not contain gzopen64), hence the error. In the previously successful build, ParaView libs are linked to gzopen in libz.a, hence no problem. But for some reason, with the new built environment, ParaView libs are now looking to link to gzopen64, hence resulting the undefined reference linking error. ParaView source and CMake files and configurations are all same between the two builds, the only difference is the build environment. After some investigation, it seems to have something to do with _LARGEFILE64_SOURCE macro definition, but I have not found anything suspicious that could cause this problem. Emailing the list in case someone has built ParaView on Titan with updated default environment PrgEnv-gnu/4.2.34 with gcc 4.8.2 and has some suggestions on fixing this linking error to make ParaView link to gzopen rather than gzopen64?

Thanks for any advice you can provide!

Regards,

Hong

From leonardopessanha74 at gmail.com  Thu Feb 27 15:11:59 2014
From: leonardopessanha74 at gmail.com (=?ISO-8859-1?Q?L=E9o_Pessanha?=)
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 2014 17:11:59 -0300
Subject: [Paraview] Adding EyeSeparationValue Mathematically
Message-ID: <CAE=GJrY=o8npX_y0pwaXp6S5bOgzW76KJNfbrNekskc1=Rr3DQ@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

I found myself facing a problem i didn`t expected

I am working on Windows 7-x64 with the binaries from kitware

I am supposed to adapt paraview to my 4-sided cave

The cave is setup in this way

________________________________________________________

LEFT | FRONT | RIGHT | FLOOR

 =

1920x1920+0+0 | 1920x1920+1920+0 | 1920x1920+3840+0 | 1920x1920+5760+0
____________________________________________________________

I`ve created the .pvx configuration file according to this, the problem was
my graphic card in some way is not compatible with the projectors (some
problem in DVI x HDMI) and i am  unable to send stereo image.

I have a configurationin the cave machine, where the machine does the job
of getting the Right Eye and the Left Eye images together.

Being able to do this i`ve setted up the .pvx configuration file this way

LEFT(Left Eye) | LEFT(Right Eye) -
FRONT(Left Eye) | FRONT(Right Eye) -
RIGHT(Left Eye) | RIGHT(Right Eye) -
FLOOR(Left Eye) | FLOOR(Right Eye)

960x1920+0+0 | 960x1920+960+0
960x1920+1920+0 | 960x1920+2880+0
960x1920+3840+0 | 960x1920+4800+0
960x1920+5760+0 | 960x1920+6720+0

With this done, my question is how to add the EyeSeparationValue
mathematically trough the vectors LowerLeft, LowerRight and UpperRight

(+ 0.03 to the right AND - 0.03 to the left)

Is this possible?
Can someone help me with this?


Att,
Leonardo Pessanha

From amit at sdsc.edu  Thu Feb 27 17:17:25 2014
From: amit at sdsc.edu (Chourasia, Amit)
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 2014 22:17:25 +0000
Subject: [Paraview] [EXTERNAL] apply texture to a slice
In-Reply-To: <CADHSJjAZnSBZRX46XkSfUV57d9_OSoWbhgksyUajuRpx_ys0PA@mail.gmail.com>
References: <98374461-5382-44E0-9C01-FF4D6C7890C5@sdsc.edu>
 <9047EE0D4D3C8E43B93980DA10A07380947711C4@EXMB04.srn.sandia.gov>
 <CADHSJjAZnSBZRX46XkSfUV57d9_OSoWbhgksyUajuRpx_ys0PA@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1D74403A-41AA-4E77-A224-D27CB373C94E@sdsc.edu>

Aha, that did the trick, thanks a bunch Utkarsh.

The following link is the top search result for "paraview texture", which is not relevant for new versions.  http://paraview.org/Wiki/ParaView:Texture

Perhaps simple steps as follows would be great to add on this page for others stumbling like me

Texturing in Paraview version 3.98+ 
1) Source > Plane
2) Filter > Texture to Plane
3) Toggle Advanced properties "cog wheel icon" next to "Search" in Properties Panel
4) search for "texture" o scroll down to Texture > load
5) Make sure your representation is surface

This change also needs to go into the new manual as its not there either.
 
-A

On Feb 27, 2014, at 11:25 AM, Utkarsh Ayachit wrote:

> Amit,
> 
> I think you're just forgetting to switch to advanced mode on the
> properties panel (or search for "texture") (refer to
> http://www.kitware.com/blog/home/post/491). You'll see the "Texture"
> combo-box to load texture under the "Miscellaneous" group. Image
> attached.
> 
> Utkarsh

>> 3) apply texture map to plane

From a.huebl at hzdr.de  Fri Feb 28 04:02:20 2014
From: a.huebl at hzdr.de (Huebl, Axel)
Date: Fri, 28 Feb 2014 10:02:20 +0100
Subject: [Paraview] Particles-in-Cells: Two XDMF files?
In-Reply-To: <530B5B09.6060609@hzdr.de>
References: <530B5B09.6060609@hzdr.de>
Message-ID: <5310509C.505@hzdr.de>

Hey,


did anyone else try combining a mesh and a polydata data set in *one*
xdmf file with paraview before?

Best,
Axel

On 24.02.2014 15:45, Huebl, Axel wrote:
> Hi ParaView mailing list,
> 
> 
> we are adding paraview/xdmf support to our particle-in-cell code
> PIConGPU [1] right now. To start with the general topology:
> 
> The particle in cell algorithm stores field data (scalars and vectors)
> on a grid, in the simplest case a 3DCoRectMesh. In between the mesh
> points live particles, described with a Polyvertex topology.
> 
> The problem that now arises: we would like to describe both grid and
> polyvertex data in the *same xdmf file*.
> 
> Doing so, e.g. by combining them on the <Domain> level in two separate
> "Temporal Collections" causes ParaView to refuse volume-rendering the
> fields (not available in the drop down menu).
> Adding two Domains to one file causes ParaView to omit the second data
> domain during load.
> Adding both grid types in the same "Temporal Collection" causes a crash.
> 
> Do we really have to write two xdmf files or did we miss a point?
> 
> A snippet of our data structures, stored in a hdf5 file per time step:
> 
> <?xml version="1.0" ?>
> <Xdmf>
>   <Domain>
>     <Grid CollectionType="Temporal" GridType="Collection" Name="Grids">
>       <Grid GridType="Uniform" Name="Grid_0_0">
>         <Topology Dimensions="256 768 256" TopologyType="3DCoRectMesh"/>
>         <Geometry Type="ORIGIN_DXDYDZ">
>           <DataItem Dimensions="3" Format="XML">0.0 0.0 0.0</DataItem>
>           <DataItem Dimensions="3" Format="XML">1.0 1.0 1.0</DataItem>
>         </Geometry>
>         <Attribute Name="fields/Density_e">
>           <DataItem Dimensions="256 768 256" Format="HDF"
> NumberType="Float" Precision="4">h5_0.h5:Density_e</DataItem>
>         </Attribute>
>       </Grid>
>       <!-- .... -->
>     </Grid>
>   </Domain>
> </Xdmf>
> 
> and the particles:
> 
> <Xdmf>
>   <Domain>
>     <Grid CollectionType="Temporal" GridType="Collection" Name="Polys">
>       <Grid GridType="Uniform" Name="Poly_0_0">
>         <Topology NodesPerElement="94109696" TopologyType="Polyvertex"/>
>         <Attribute Name="particles/e/weighting">
>           <DataItem Dimensions="94109696" Format="HDF"
> NumberType="Float" Precision="4">h5_0.h5:weighting</DataItem>
>         </Attribute>
>         <Time TimeType="Single" Value="0"/>
>         <Attribute AttributeType="Vector" Name="particles/e/momentum">
>           <DataItem Dimensions="94109696 3" Function="JOIN($0,$1,$2)"
> ItemType="Function">
>             <DataItem Dimensions="94109696" Format="HDF"
> NumberType="Float" Precision="4">h5_0.h5:momentum/x</DataItem>
>             <DataItem Dimensions="94109696" Format="HDF"
> NumberType="Float" Precision="4">h5_0.h5:momentum/y</DataItem>
>             <DataItem Dimensions="94109696" Format="HDF"
> NumberType="Float" Precision="4">h5_0.h5:momentum/z</DataItem>
>           </DataItem>
>         </Attribute>
>       </Grid>
>       <!-- .... -->
>     </Grid>
>   </Domain>
> </Xdmf>
> 
> 
> Best regards and thanks for your Feedback,
> Axel Huebl
> 
> [1] http://picongpu.hzdr.de
> 

-- 
.....................................................

. a.huebl at hzdr.de          - Phone +49 351 260 3582 .
.            https://www.hzdr.de/crp                .
.                                                   .
. Computational Radiation Physics                   .
. Laser Particle Acceleration Division              .

From felipe.bordeu at ec-nantes.fr  Fri Feb 28 04:23:51 2014
From: felipe.bordeu at ec-nantes.fr (Felipe Bordeu)
Date: Fri, 28 Feb 2014 10:23:51 +0100
Subject: [Paraview] Particles-in-Cells: Two XDMF files?
In-Reply-To: <5310509C.505@hzdr.de>
References: <530B5B09.6060609@hzdr.de> <5310509C.505@hzdr.de>
Message-ID: <531055A7.5010203@ec-nantes.fr>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

I think the way to doit is to :

>>  by combining them on the <Domain> level in two separate
>> "Temporal Collections" causes ParaView to refuse volume-rendering the
>> fields (not available in the drop down menu).

then use the "Extract Block" to extract the 3DCoRectMesh. The problem is
that the output still a Multi-block Dataset, so you have to use a "Merge
Block" to eliminate the multi-block structure.

Maybe a good idea is to modified the "Extract Block" (or add an option)
to eliminate the multi-block structure when only one mesh is selected.

You can test this creating a "Wavelet" and a "Disk" then group them
using "GroupDataset" and apply the procedure.


Felipe

Subject: [Paraview] NEK5000 with ParaView
In-Reply-To: <CAM8hOwb4+VAJHmCHA8Moge-wSpupCSYk0-XKR3T8M-ocmv1OJQ@mail.gmail.com>
References: <21387967-078C-4B04-A45E-39556BAC7CED@gmail.com>

Hello Patrick and Giuseppe,

I am also facing the same issue as Giuseppe did on visualizing the NEK5000
solution data. I have simulated a moving boundary problem using NEK5000,
and have the output saved in *.fld* format. When I load the meta file to
read the files in Paraview, only one time-step mesh geometry is loaded,
whereas the field results of all the time-steps are available in Paraview.

I would appreciate if either of you could suggest any workaround to read
the moving mesh geometry which is saved for each time-step of the solution.

I am trying to read my NEK5000 output in version 4.1.0 64-bit Paraview
installation. If you want the data files, please let me know, I can send
them across.

Thanks in advance for you help.

Sincerely,
Ravi

Subject: [Paraview] [EXTERNAL]  a new user with a simple question
In-Reply-To: <9047EE0D4D3C8E43B93980DA10A07380946E891E@EXMB04.srn.sandia.gov>
References: <CAPpq9iomrzcTaNGvpN_FjKZzrXFCSgxO8zJmjXpPwc=vawVpCg@mail.gmail.com>
 <9047EE0D4D3C8E43B93980DA10A07380946E891E@EXMB04.srn.sandia.gov>

I tried rm paraview .ini  file and indeed got a fresh start with paraFoam
(by looking at the "Recent" tab under "Filter").   However, on one of
my computers (unlike the others) the plotOverLine window is still blank
(without anything visible, not even the coordinates).  I tried to put in a
"Chart Title" but it does not appear in the blank window (although colors
were assigned to data sets).  I tried "Save Data" and looked at the csv
file, which shows the data were there.  which might be due to that the data
did not get in there.   Could there be something else I can do to manually
get the data (over line) plotted in that window?   Thanks.


On Wed, Jan 22, 2014 at 1:25 PM, Scott, W Alan <wascott at sandia.gov> wrote:

>  This web site tells you how to do it - from the ParaView Wiki.
> http://www.paraview.org/Wiki/ParaView_Settings_Files.  Just delete the
> configuration files.
>
>
>
> You can also find out if taking ParaView to initial conditions is what you
> want.  Run paraview -dr (disable registry), and that does the same thing as
> deleting the configuration files.
>
>
>
> Alan
>
